item.title: Coffee Menu Madness
item.dc:creator: hookcoffee
item.content:encoded:
Coffee menus are a labyrinth. Many would gladly study abstract maths or pay taxes rather than choose a drink off of some coffee menus. It's true. It's intimidating to order off a confusing coffee menu. Sometimes baristas fail to answer questions or truly help with your decision making process. To make things worse, some shops interpret types of drinks differently. A macchiato at one shop could be different than the same beverage somewhere else. Today we are going to look at some traditional and popular drinks that you'll come across during your coffee journey. It won't clear up all confusion, but visiting this drink guide on a need-to-know basis could come in handy.  

There are three kinds of coffee shop menus:

Type I: Clean, elegant, and small with maybe four drinks on it. Many prefer this type of shop, but even a menu like this can be intimidating to the newcomer. The lack of choice can make you feel exposed in a way. Menus like this usually feature brewed coffee, espresso, espresso + milk, and maybe a signature beverage. The beautiful idea behind this menu is the simplicity. For brewed coffee, maybe a single brew method or a large batch Fetco brewer is used. The espresso drinks are simple with no flavor options. Type II: This menu features a large variety of drinks, but all are traditional. This is perhaps the most intimidating of the menu types. To the coffee newcomer, a menu like this can seem akin to a different language. Most specialty shops use menus in this style. There are at least five types of espresso drinks listed on the menu along with other options. After signature beverages and cold brew / brewed coffee options, this menu can get big. It's great that shops feature so many classics on one menu. If the mission of the establishment is to be hospitable and intentional, this menu works. It just takes time for the newbie to adapt to all of the noise. Type III: Flavors. Pages upon pages of crazy drink names. Size names that don't make sense. These menus are the worst. Even for the coffee veteran. Trying to understand a menu like this will cause a headache or migraine. When a menu has over three or four flavor options (to add to an espresso drink), you're in trouble. That's a good sign that the shop isn't attuned to the intricacies of coffee flavor. A coffee shop should be able to communicate to its patrons. If their menu is completely different than every other menu - straying away from traditional drinks and the like - there is something wrong. Before we go on we need to disclose a few coffee trade secrets. That's right, secrets. Know that in the coffee community, there are standards but not rules. Most coffee purveyors that serve stellar coffee abide by specialty coffee standards set out by the SCAA, SCAE, SCA, or another organized collective. However many shops kind of do their own thing. The drinks described below will be manipulated and changed depending on the need of the consumer. So the secret is that drinks aren't all the same. There are ongoing discussions and debates concerning the efficacy of certain drink methodologies within the coffee community. Just try to understand the general principles. Also, in the coffee world "traditional" doesn't always mean, "according to the past." Traditional sometimes means "the most popular." Yes, it's confusing.  

So here's a list of some drinks:

Machiatto Espresso to coffee ratio - 2:1 (two parts espresso for every part of milk) This beverage puts espresso on the forefront. The milk generally consists of a light foam to round out the espresso flavor and add texture. Usually served as a 3oz.   Cortado Espresso to coffee ratio - 1:1 The cortado is meant to capture the espresso and milk flavor equally. The milk has a thin layer of micro foam. Usually served as a 4.5 oz.   Gibraltar Espresso to coffee ratio - 1:1 Many would argue that this drink is the same as a Cortado, except that it's served in a Gibraltar glass. Served as a 4.5 oz.   Cappuccino Espresso to coffee ratio - 1:2 Meant to capture the sweetness of the milk without cutting the complex notes of espresso, the Cappuccino is a favorite of espresso lovers. The foam on top is about a centimeter thick. Usually served in a 5-6 oz.   Flat White Espresso to coffee ratio - 1:2 The Flat White is similar to a Cappuccino, but it's purpose is different. The Cappuccino highlights milk (pairing with espresso), while the Flat White Highlights the complexity of espresso. There is a slight layer of micro foam on the surface. Usually served in a 5-6 oz.   Latte Espresso to coffee ratio - 1:3 The latte's excess of milk rounds out espresso into a light, sweet flavor. If flavors are to be added, this is the beverage of choice. A light layer of micro foam shines across the surface. Usually served as an 8 oz. or greater.   There are of course more drinks - many more. We chose to highlight some of the more confusing milk beverages. If you are interested in other beverages, research and see what you'll find. It's a big world. Happy brewing everyone! The Hook Coffee Team

item.title: Define Fresh.
item.dc:creator: hookcoffee
item.content:encoded:
We're committed to connecting good coffee to good people - you all deserve nothing but the best! We will be telling you why we are obsessed about freshness at Hook and why a fresh cup is the best cup and what exactly we mean when we say we've some of the freshest coffees in town!

So go on, grab a fresh cup of coffee - hopefully ours - and get ready to learn something new.

We’ve all had cups of coffee that have instantly made our day. Rich, flavourful, and possessing an aroma to die for - these are the words that come to mind when you think about a fresh cup of coffee, right?

The freshness of your coffee is determined the very moment it is sent to be roasted. Coffee doesn't actually start out looking like a brown bean. Instead, they start as green beans when they are brought to the roaster. The roasting profile and process are crucial to bringing out the inherent characteristics and flavours of the coffees - bold/light, floral/fruity, chocolatey/caramel-y... And as long as your coffee is FRESH, you'll be able to enjoy these delicious flavours! But the flavours and aroma weaken and wane over time. Take a look at this chart below!You might be wondering what on earth "de-gassing" is! It's basically the process where the beans release carbon dioxide, the molecules rest and settle, for a richer, smoother, and more balanced cup. Since we send out your coffee to you within a week of roasting, by the time you receive it, your coffee is at it’s best for consumption.

Storage tips: Mum might have told you keeping coffees in the fridge or freezer, or any food/drink really, is the best way to preserve their freshness and extend their shelf life. Unfortunately, mum’s wrong this time (sorry, mum!). When it comes to storing coffee, the key elements to protect it from are excessive air, moisture, heat and light. The bags we use to pack and deliver your coffees are perfect for doing all that. You can always transfer your coffees out, as long as it’s in an airtight (ideally opaque) container and kept in a cool, dry place.

Now that you've been enlightened, think about the "fresh" coffee you've ever bought from coffee chains and much less supermarkets. Can you imagine how stale the coffee is?

[caption id="attachment_1489" align="aligncenter" width="600"] (image via http://www.sheknows.com/food-and-recipes/articles/961051/how-to-oven-roast-your-own-coffee)[/caption]

The freshness of your coffee is clearly critical but the  segment of the coffee industry that has commoditised specialty coffee has a way of tricking you into believing your coffee is still "fresh".

Most coffee you get at the supermarket are roasted ages ago if you actually pick up a bag of coffee and look for the roasting date (which most of the time they do not reveal). And the trick to mask the staleness of a supermaket market coffee, is to roast it really dark. The result? Coffee that just taste bitter and nothing else. We wrote an article on how to read a coffee pacaking like a pro, here is the article if you haven't already check it out.

Customers, however, also often don’t notice this because the bad taste is masked by massive amounts of sugar and syrup pumped into their cups. A Grande Mocha Frappuccino, for example, contains 61g of sugar. (According tHhis is given that within 24 to 72 hours of roasting, coffee beans slowly go stale after having been exposed to oxygen. Beans stored for too long tend to produce flat and stale tasting coffee, which is often what you get at larger chains. This applies for both the coffee drinks they sell you, and their bagged beans.

Now, we’re not trying to preach here or anything, but these are just a few things you should remember before buying that cup of coffee. Sure it’s quick and convenient, but it might not be actually what’s best for your body, or for the farmers who contributed to producing it via methods other than direct trade. If you’re looking for a quick fix, consider using freshly ground coffee beans (maybe even ours!) or a drip bag instead. You could even try learning how to brew your own coffee with the V60 - it’s super easy and honestly doesn’t take that long!

We hope this post has been insightful for you, and will be useful as you continue looking for the best coffee to drink. After all, what better way to start your Monday morning than by learning something new?

Have a great weekend, and thanks for reading!

Happy Brewing!

Love,

The Hook Team

item.title: Cupping Coffee - what does this mean?
item.dc:creator: hookcoffee
item.content:encoded:
Maybe you've heard of the term "cupping coffee." Roasters write about their flavor discoveries during the cupping process. You maybe have seen shops hosting weekly cuppings. It seems like everyone is doing it. Well, what is it? The easiest answer is that it is a tool. Cupping is a process where people come together to taste coffee before it is sold. More than that, it is an efficient process in which tasting takes place. Notes are jotted down, discussions are ample, and decisions are made. All cupping decisions go back to the roaster. Even further than that, cupping notes can lead to roasting an entirely different coffee.  

Here's a brief on how cupping works.

A table is set up with little cups and saucers around the perimeter. There is a cup of spoons in the center of the table, ready for all the participants of the cupping.

First - Get the Dry Aroma

Each of the cups is filled with ground coffee. The cupping participants then smell each of the cups and take notes. This is called the dry aroma. Many things can be determined just from smelling the freshly ground coffee. If one smells dried apricots and chocolate in an Ethiopian coffee, that can be a sign that the beans were roasted in the right ballpark. If instead one smells surface cleaner and toast, that can be a sign that something went wrong during the roasting period. Notes are taken for further inspection.  

Second - Get the Wet Aroma

After the dry aroma is analyzed, water is poured onto the grounds. Once the grounds are brewed for a short time (details are discussed later in the article), the cupping participants break the crust of coffee that formed on the surface. This wet slurry of coffee is holding in much of the aroma. When the crust is broken by stirring with a spoon, aroma explosion happens. All the participants now smell each of the coffees and take notes. Keep in mind that the wet aroma is just as important as the dry aroma. Good coffee should stretch beyond the realm of flavor. Smell and taste go together. In this step, cuppers dissect each of the sensory imprints of a particular coffee. Instead of just brewing and tasting, cupping separates coffee into parts to be analyzed and perfected. Aroma is a very important part.

Third - Taste and Slurp

Once the water cools to around 71 degrees Celsius, tasting takes place. Each of the cuppers takes a spoonful of coffee and slurps it. Like, really slurps it. It can get loud in a cupping room. Slurping is done to intensify the flavor of the coffee. When almost breathing in coffee in a slurping fashion, the aroma is taken into the nose, the pores in the cheeks are saturated with coffee, and initial flavors that hit the mouth become abundantly clear. The coffee is tasted to point out unpleasant notes, and to observe palatable ones. Cuppers try to find notes like aluminum, detergent, or dirt. These bad, abstract notes can tell the roaster something that is going on, or they can point out coffee defects to green coffee buyers. As the brew cools, different notes become apparent. Once the temperature falls below 21 degrees Celsius, the observation stops. So that's the gist of cupping. We do it, and every other roaster does it. We find it educating and necessary.  

More in depth cupping instruction:

Time between roast and cupping - let the coffee rest after roast for at least 10 hours before cupping. Cup within 24 hours. Ratio of water to coffee - 18:1 We use 150-200 ml of water Grind - medium-coarse grind. Don't wait more than 15 minutes to infuse with water Water - Water should be poured at around 93 degrees Celsius. Brew time before wet aroma is 3-5 minutes. The coffee is measured for balance, acidity, clarity, mouthfeel, aroma, aftertaste, sweetness...and more. We try to analyze every aspect of the coffee before shipping it out to you all.   Try cupping with your friends! While it won't be a "true" after roast cupping, you can learn a ton. Thanks everyone. Happy cupping! The Hook Coffee Team

item.title: Entering the Coffee Industry
item.dc:creator: hookcoffee
item.content:encoded:
Drinking coffee is a daily ritual for the masses. Even those who could care less about flavor, drink coffee every day. The drink is consumed as a caffeine booster, a delightful experience in cuisine, or to partake in cultural norms. A lot of people drink coffee. It's one of the worlds most valued commodities. And many people are beginning to truly value coffee as a craft. Which means that more and more are making their living within the coffee industry. There are quite a few job facets within the coffee industry. Roasters essentially "cook" the green beans that come from farmers. Before that, farmers ship off the green beans to green coffee buyers. Those beans are tested and validated through quality graders. That coffee is of course, roasted. Then coffee shops then purchase those roasted beans, and baristas prepare the coffee for consumption (the seed to cup process). Lots of jobs exist within this industry, and it's only growing. If you love coffee, working in the coffee industry could be a viable option for the future. So how does one enter into the coffee industry, especially without any experience? Today we will be talking a bit about how to procure a job in the coffee industry.   We usually focus on home brewing tips and the like, but we realize that many of you wish to go further. Maybe you came across some tasty Hook coffee, learned from our guides, and now you love the craft. A similar circumstance happens with most everyone that finds themselves in this industry: they taste amazing things in a cup of coffee, they dig deeper, and they find themselves supporting their families by working as a barista or roaster. Coffee brings people together, and those people seem to be obsessed with quality and community.

For the remainder of this post, let's focus on a popular job in this industry: the barista

  Understand the coffee basics We've discussed extraction theory in the past. Understanding AND practicing the craft of coffee extraction takes discipline. A myriad of variables must be kept in mind - temperature, grind size, agitation, brew method, bean varietal, elevation and density, water chemistry... the list goes on. In the most competent of specialty shops, baristas must adapt on the fly. If something doesn't work, you need to know why it doesn't work. To do this you need to practice intentional brewing every day. If something doesn't taste good, brew another cup and try to fix it. Keep in mind that some of the best baristas started as home brewers! Relevant literature: The Professional Barista Handbook by Scott Rao   Hospitality A barista is the bridge between good coffee and the consumer. Coffee quality is important, but it is not as important as being a hospitable host. We wrote an article on the subject of coffee snobbery that explains the dangers of not being hospitable in the coffee industry. Specialty coffee is already viewed as a pretentious niche craft. To combat this perception, we must be kind and educate everyone! The customer is more than just a paying client. The customer is a potential member of the coffee community. Relevant literature: Setting the Table by Danny Meyer   Get to know the Team If you wish to work as a barista, especially at a particular shop, try becoming a regular. Drink coffee there a couple of times a week to get to know the staff and the owner of the establishment. Again, specialty coffee is about community. You probably won't get hired at a worthwhile shop if you hand in an application and never follow up. You need to gauge whether or not this workplace is good for you. Maybe the coffee served at a particular shop is great but the culture of the company doesn't match your style. If you are serious about making a living as a barista, work with a team that you love! Money isn't everything. Sure, you need to be compensated as a barista expert, but working in a culture that values you is imperative. Relevant information: Coffee Jobs Podcast (available on most podcast mediums)   Be Relevant Cultures shift and change. Now more than ever, information comes and goes. The world is faster than us. If you are serious about a life in coffee, keep up with trends. Listen to podcasts. Read Books. Find out what gear you like. Stay current and find others that can make you grow as a barista!   We hope this painted a path for those looking to enter the coffee workforce. For those satisfied with the home brewing life, keep doing what you love! You don't have to work in the coffee industry to enjoy it. Coffee is for everyone.   Keep brewing everybody! The Hook Coffee Team
